narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Good
This course was great for a math major pursuing a BS, I learned a lot about approximations as well as obviously a substantive amount of Quantum Mechanics
Advanced quantum mechanics, including spin, perturbation theory, approximations and scattering theory.

Course covers the second half of Shankars book: hydrogen atom, spin, variational and WKB methods, scattering theory, perturbation theory, Dirac equation. You definitely learn how to DO quantum mechanics, but I felt like some of the intuition was lacking sometimes.
Acquired a working understanding of quantum mechanics and how scientific experiment gives rise to theories.

Extension of concepts developed in the first semester of quantum mechanics. In-depth study of angular momentum, spin, the solution to the hydrogen atom and the energy corrections due to spin and relativistic interactions, a review of the variational method and nondegenerate and degenerate perturbation theory, introduction to the WKB method and the Dirac equation. Gaining familiarity with solution approaches common to all quantum mechanics problems.
Perturbation theory (time dependent / independent, degenerate, non-degenerate), scattering, angular momentum addition, dirac equation
Spin, spin dynamics, addition of angular momentum, approximation methods, scattering, and dirac equation

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Good professor
The problem set questions couldve been a little bit more relevant, but overall it was a great course.

Strengths: Prof Shankar is great at explaining concepts; he has written the canonical undergrad textbook and has years of experience teaching. Weaknesses: Can't think of any. The class involves mastering challenging material, but exams and homework are very much doable.
The course was excellent. Shankar is an excellent professor who provides all the resources necessary to succeed in his class.

The course is very well structured, content builds logically and is in resonance with problem sets and exams. However, students coming from PHYS 439 will find a lot of overlap and review of topics already covered, especially in angular momentum, spin, and perturbation theory.
I wouldn't know how this course can be done better. Maybe a better location so that the construction outside SPL isn't distracting?
Lectures were hard to follow and could have benefited from greater detail

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, if you need it
Yes, if youre at all interested in quantum mechanics its great!
absolutely, especially if Shankar is teaching it. He pauses lecture often to ask for questions and is extremely committed to communicating the material.
The mystifying world of quantum theory only becomes clear in talking about spin and angular momentum addition - my favorite topic of this class. Definitely take it if you liked 440!
Yes

A must take for students interested in physics. I would highly recommend that Math majors looking to fulfill their BS science requirement opt for QM over more traditional choices like 401-402 or 410-430.

Good course to take if you wish to study quantum mechanics at a high level. However, you must be prepared to put in the work for this course. The assignments from before spring break are time consuming, and took more than 10hrs per week to complete.

The course is a well-paced and appropriately rigorous expansion of the quantum toolkit for any student of physics. For anyone studying solid-state, electronic, or optical systems, this course is an effective preparation.
Definitely if you are a physics major (intensive or not), or a chem major who is into physical chemistry.
